Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2: Acquisition of a Confocal Raman Microscope
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program Professor Vartkess A. Apkarian and colleagues Rachel Martin, Reginald M. Penner and Eric Potma from the Department of Chemistry at the University of California-Irvine (UCI) will acquire a confocal Raman microscope to facilitate research at the NSF Center for Chemical Innovation on Chemistry at the Space-Time Limit and the UCI Center for Solar Energy. The instrument will be broadly utilized for the molecular characterization of fabricated novel materials, nano-structured devices for solar cells, single molecule devices based on nano-tube and nano-wire platforms, nano-catalysts, polycrystalline hydrates and protein aggregates. These are all examples of heterogeneous specimens in which molecular composition and function greatly vary with space.

A confocal Raman microscope is a highly flexible instrument, principally used for the non-destructive chemical characterization of heterogeneous specimens. Raman spectra allow the identification of molecular structure and environment. The confocal Raman microscope produces images of specimens, consisting of spectra obtained with a spatial resolution of 1 micrometer. The instrument will be an integral part teaching and research activities of two research centers and will in addition serve the broader research communities at UCI.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project entailed bringing Raman microscopy capabilities to a significant community of researchers involved in diverse fields of science and technology at UCI. To this end, a commercial confocal Raman microscope (Renishaw InVia) was purchased and was installed in the Laser Spectroscopy Facility of the Department of Chemistry. The facility and the instrument were managed by a PhD scientist, Dr. Wytze van der Veer, who has extensive experience both as researcher and instructor of modern optics, laser technologies, and spectroscopy.  During the period of the award, 45 researchers were trained as users, 15 research groups from the Physical Sciences and Engineering made extensive use of the instrument, along with two nearby companies (RFNano Corp. and Aerospace Corp.). In the majority of cases the Raman microscope was used as an invaluable tool for characterizing samples, by spatially mapping out their chemical composition, as part of a larger projects. In a smaller number of cases, micro-Raman spectroscopy was the main method of investigation on which the principal findings were based, and as such, the use of the Center instrument was acknowledged. More than 20 papers have already appeared in which data acquired by the Center Raman microscope has been noted.

In addition to research, the instrument has been used in the instructional and outreach programs of the NSF Center for Chemical Innovation (CCI) on Chemistry at the Space-Time Limit (CaSTL), which was the leading group in the original proposal. Raman microscopy was used in the graduate Laboratory Skills course offered to students of Chemical and Materials Physics in which nano-materials were synthesized, deposited and detected. The instrument was also used in the summer program aimed at high schools students in a project in which the phenomenon of surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) was illustrated on colloidal gold particles.

Here, we highlight one major research accomplishment in which the confocal microscope has played a major role.

Raman microscopy allows imaging of the chemical composition of samples with ~ 0.5 micron spatial resolution. This is accomplished by combining a confocal microscope with a Raman spectrometer and by using the vibrational spectra of molecules to fingerprint them. Although universal, Raman is a feeble effect, which leads to ~ 1 detectable photon for every 107-1010 incident from a laser. Ever since the discovery of surface enhanced Raman scatttering (SERS) effect in mid 70’s, that roughened metallic surfaces enhance the Raman signal by more than six orders of magnitude, there has been a major push to stretch the detection sensitivity to the single molecule limit. The original discovery was made at Nortwestern by R. P. Van Duyne, who is currently a member of the CaSTL Center. Another group in the Center, led by Apkarian, used the Renishaw microscope to successfully demonstrate that single molecules can be detected by equipping them with nano-dumbbell antennae, consisting of a pair of silver nano-spheres. They demonstrated that not only single antennaed molecules can be detected under ambient conditions, but that also their Raman spectra can be used to track the orientation of molecules in 3D space. In effect, in this application, SERS serves as a global positioning system (GPS) of molecules. The logical next step to this – observing single molecule chemistry – has already been reported in the form of seeing the formation and breaking of sulfur-metal bonds by the same group. With the same generality, they also have shown that single molecule SERS at nano-junctions can be use to measure local electric fields with 1 nm spatial resolution.
